replies.commentBody:
Actually, the Russians swayed the election by exposing the CONTENT of the DNC emails. The fact that the DNC was hacked had zero impact on the election - it was what the DNC was saying internally.

Here is an analogy: The Pentagon Papers did not turn American opinion against the Vietnam war - the CONTENT of the Pentagon Papers did. Ellsberg was considered a hero, so why wouldn't the Russians be?

QED, for the same reason court trials include both a prosecution and defense. Leaking Democratic documents without ALSO releasing the corresponding Republican material for comparison is not an altruistic revelation to serve democracy. It's just a foreign power using espionage to manipulate our election for ita own purposes.

I'm sorry your short-sightedness prevents you from seeing the big picture -- that foreign powers act for their own interests, not ours.

Disagree, QED. I know of few people, and most were Sanders supporters, who familiarized themselves with the content of the emails or cared much about what they actually said. (I agree that the emails showed the institutional favoritism of the DNC toward Clinton; but keep in mind that despite the many positives Sanders brought to the race, he only declared his party affiliation in order to run, and he lost legitimately at the polls in an election year when the RNC was taken over by an outside.)

What I kept hearing was just "emails, emails, Hillary used a private email server." I didn't hear people talk about the content of the emails much; they were just a source of mysterious taint. Even now, you aren't enumerating what scandals or improprieties they revealed. The equivalent RNC emails weren't made public, and that created an impression that there was nothing to reveal in contrast to the Democratic side.

I actually don't think the hack affected the outcome of the election that much. It was more the continuing vague and undermining insinuations (they didn't even rise to the level of accusation) that Comey then perpetuated.

comments.commentBody: The investigation should be about treason, pure and simple.

replies.commentBody:
"This story is just the latest effort by Obama to delegitimize Trump"

You're right, all those years that Obama accused Trump of being born in Africa and demanding to see his long-form birth certificate and charging he was not a legitimate president — wasn't that ugly? Wasn't that disgusting? Who could support a vicious, divisive, irresponsible liar like that?

Not that I buy your reasoning, but turnabout is certainly fair play, given that our current President began his rise to political prominence by questioning the legitimacy of the Obama Presidency in the most heinous way. He knowingly spread ridiculous lies that defamed the President and showed utter contempt for the office he now holds. From that moment on our Liar-in-Chief demonstrated that he was unfit for the office he now holds. He deserves whatever accusations that are now hurled at him, whether true or not.

Amen, Neal. All of this talk about "coming together" is just so much nonsense, considering that our President's fanatical supporters have given their tacit approval for such despicable behavior. Anyone who would vote for a candidate that promoted the heinous lie of "birtherism" has no respect for this country's values and institutions.

comments.commentBody: This story is just the latest effort by Obama to delegitimize Trump, and comes conspicuously the day he is seeing a bump in approvals from his speech.

Every individual who kept the Russia connections out in the open is a patriot.  The relations between Trump and Putin conceal something foul.  Those in power must never be allowed to use that power to cover their tracks.

replies.commentBody: Conducted by Tinkerbell?
With a special prosecutor after sessions resigns.

Let do it again folks, to save democracy.

comments.commentBody:
Trump will be impeached or forced to resign, mark my words. It always comes down to the money. What this trail of evidence will prove is that Trump was receiving dirty laundered Russian funds from Bank of America and/or Bank of Cyprus. None of the US banks would loan to him; he was too much of a credit risk. So the Russians controlled by Putin effectively ended up supplying him badly needed cash. And then, as a result, the Russians and Putin owned him and still own him. THAT'S why he inexplicably has been so unbelievably complimentary to Putin. And that's why an incredibly high number of his cabinet have not just ties but very deep ties to Russia, including Wilbur Ross, who had and/or has a huge ownership position in, you guessed it, Bank of Cyprus, where a lot of the dirty money to Trump may have come from.

Trump's deplorable show of marketing the deceased SEAL's widow to his own despicable benefit will have the half-life of a firefly in August. It's not going to last.

Stay on him New York Times. It will all come out, not just in the end, but maybe sooner than we think.

replies.commentBody: If they did that, it means they have a conscience. They could then become Democrats.

This would not be necessary if Congress simply invoked their investigative power.

The stakes were so high during the 2016 campaign that they should have acted as soon as the Intelligence Assessment confirmed this activity was going on. They should not have simply stood by, or relied on a Democratic Administration to be the only defense, due to the appearance of partiality.

Congress was *derelict* in its duty in this time of obvious peril to the principle of free and fair elections.

Why is the nation in peril? What's the evidence? That RT continued to air alternative POVs from American citizens? That someone disagreed with the mainstream narrative? Seriously, what's your evidence?

comments.commentBody: One of these anonymous sources must put country first and speak on the record. Yes, it will destroy their career and likely get them arrested but the Nation is in such peril

replies.commentBody: It's called collaboration. We saw it in Nazi-occupied Europe, and we saw what happened when the resistance took hold. Patience and organization are key to purging our nation of these individuals by developing the facts and trials.

Yes. Frankly, this is the larger issue for me. Let the efforts to impeach Trump drag on and on. Let there be stonewalling and caterwalling, because with a Pence presidency and the Repugnicants in charge of both houses, some very bad ideas will become law. As corrupt as Trump clearly is, and as beholden to the Russians as he clearly is, he is less beholden to Ryan et al's dreams of destroying the 'entitlements'. It's the long game right now. What we resistors need to do is raise doubts and push (but not too hard) to impeach Trump. This needs to take a LOT of time...

There is clearly a bigger picture at stake than whether or not the Trump administration is at the beck and call of the Russians. There are truly coherent Republican imperatives that require Trump's very quick evisceration at stake here, too, and it would be strategically awful to enable them.

comments.commentBody: Will any of these revelations and intelligence be of use when we have a Republican Congress more than willing to look the other way in order to get their anti-progressive agenda enacted by the current Liar-in-Chief?

replies.commentBody:
I suggest that you and other NYT readers study the legal definition of treason. You will find to your disappointment that none of this comes close in any way. It's a pity that your comment was chosen by the NYT as one of their "picks" as it encourages this hysteria.
If there were to have been any criminal activity, and none has been found to date, there could be charges. Treason would not be among them.
Why not show us the evidence before leveling charges of treason?

Article III Section 3: Treason against the United States, shall consist only in levying War against them, or in adhering to their Enemies, giving them Aid and Comfort. No Person shall be convicted of Treason unless on the Testimony of two Witnesses to the same overt Act, or on Confession in open Court.

In NY we teach that in seventh grade. Now take a breath and go for a walk.

comments.commentBody: It's called treason. Let's start writing the word in these articles. Inviting a foreign government's intelligence agencies to hack politicians computers in order to steal the election — treason. I hated Hillary and her husband more than most Trump voters, but I still understand that the Russian Government has no place in american politics.

A lot of conjecture, innuendo and allegations. Either there is an organized and frantic effort to coverup treasonable activities or Trump and his campaign had a lot of Russian contacts for purely social reasons. At the rate Russians and their helpers are dropping dead it may already be too late to get to the truth.

replies.commentBody: Your last sentence is the part that I find most horrific.

This is a treason writ well. A tangled web of persons out of their depth and a foreign power who has invested well to ensnare them.

They have been trapped by their deceit and entwined by their lies. They still don't see the transparency of their treason. They shamelessly make a song and dance of the leaks, AKA the truth revealed, as the only crime here and have tried hard to cover their tracks. The snow will soon melt.

The puzzle is coming together. The spies are doing their work. When the case is built this house of cards will blow over in the warm winds of spring.

It will be a hot summer.

Bannon knows his history, Beware the Reichstag.

A dying elephant can do a lot of damage.
Specifically democrats (and republicans) in congress that were briefed. The expressions of shock on the faces of democrats coming out were breathtaking. It was obvious a coup took place.

comments.commentBody: Important new puzzle pieces in this expanding web of espionage. I think it is only a matter of time until this blows wide open. There are people who know the whole truth but can say nothing for now

replies.commentBody: no pun intended

comments.commentBody:
Good for those then in power to do this. In the final analysis their loyalty to the country led them to attempt to preserve the truth, aware that a delusional an narcissistic egomaniac and his alternative facts team would try to rewrite history.
I have no doubt that our so-called POTUS will see these folks as contemptible and treasonous, but I also have no doubt that these individuals will sleep well at night knowing they did the right thing and for the right reasons.

This story reminds me of the old Mad Magazine feature Spy versus Spy. Unlike Mad Magazine this story is no laughing matter but will anyone who reports to President Trump, either directly or indirectly, have the courage to display whatever evidence has been preserved? Who will oversee the continued preservation of information and who will supervise its systematic collection and analysis? There's ample opportunity for mischief, including the destruction of important documents and evidence. The public deserves disclosure of any tampering and collusion, if such activities occurred. The matter deserves full and independent investigating, not as a partisan issue, but for the well-being of future elections.

replies.commentBody:
In reply to your question, Ms.Kerr, "What are the GOP members of Congress hiding by refusing to authorize a special select committee?" I believe this Republican dominated Congress is not about to rock their boat.

Look at the Cheshire Cat grin on Senator McConnell during that recent address to the joint session of the legislature. The GOP has a lock on their puppet who is busy tearing down nearly everything R's have opposed since FDR. It's not lack of courage to oppose Trump's agenda, but a complete lack of a social conscience.

jp - If there was nothing wrong, why did he lie about it?

comments.commentBody: What are the GOP members of Congress hiding by refusing to authorize a special select committee?  And what is Trump hiding by refusing to release his tax returns?  At this point, silence equals complicity - at least in the eyes of a growing majority of Americans who support full and immediate investigation of Russian influence/control in our White House.

replies.commentBody:
@Chris Miilu: since the US Constitution has not changed on this issue (the Electoral College) in all of our 240 years....and since the EC was a critical component of the 2000 Election crisis only 16 years earlier....it would be pretty shocking if polls DID NOT take into effect the Electoral College. In fact, did they not, it would invalidate all of their polling measures, and I'd seriously doubt their abilities to conduct ANY polls in the future!

I read numerous Upshot columns that discussed the results, popular vote vs. Electoral College results, and Nate Cohen (as well as Nate Silver on his own 538 blog) analyzed this over and over, with the conclusion that....while Trump had a tiny chance of pulling out a POPULAR vote win....he had absolutely zero chance in the Electoral College, precisely because Hillary was SUPPOSED to have all those "safe states" in the Midwest.

Now, with the perfect clarity of 20/20 hindsight, we know the exact opposite happened. Meaning the pollsters were whistling in the dark and don't know diddley squat.

So when the Founders created the EC 72 years before the Civil War they anticipated Reconstruction and gave this gift to slaveholders in advance? The EC served its well-defined purpose this election; it prevented Los Angeles and NYC (the 2 cities providing Clinton's mythical popular vote "victory") from determining the outcome.

Your ignorance is profound.
She won by nearly 3,000,000 votes well the entire Republican Party trump the FBI, The Russians and Bernie all conspired against her.

comments.commentBody: An independent investigation should be launched to investigate whether voting machines were hacked as well.  Polls may not be completely accurate but it is hard to believe that the pre-election poll results showing Hillary Clinton with such a big lead would be so far off.

It is an eternal game, unfortunately. Is there any wonder politicians have such low credibility among ordinary people?

replies.commentBody: They were  hacking into voters registration records in several states.  Russia wanted Trump to win.  There were several items in the newspapers about it.  Someone also hacked Pelosi records.  There were other things published up to election day.  Trust no one,

That is not logical. Our political parties seek the best advantage. If the Obama administration had incontrovertible proof they would have happily provided it to destroy Trump.

You are trying very hard to make it seem like you have a point. You do not. The Obama administration would not have waited until they saw who won the election to decide to release the fact that a hostile foreign power was interfering. What would be the motive? There was no downside for the Democrats, Obama, or Clinton.

Your comment is nonsense. I ask you to respond and answer the question as to what motive the Democrats, et. al. would have to keep this information secret.
@Paul:  Selective memory?  Then Obama wasn't POTUS?

comments.commentBody:
This is all a cover the butt story for why the Obama administration waited to identify and punish Russian hacking until after the election - even though they had evidence a year before that. They thought Hillary was going to win.

So if it was so "important" that it could wait for a year, and could depend on who won the election, it was not that important.

Contact between Russian officials and private US citizens is not illegal. Russia's hacking of the DNC, while reprehensible, is the hacking of a private organization, not the government. It certainly is not "hacking the election".

AND, what was the result? Exposing actual facts, truth, about DNC and its minions.

replies.commentBody: If that is true, and I am not sure that it is, the current actions will be no worse than what the Republicans tried to do--in every way they could--throughout the Obama Administration. And then, all of those Benghazi investigations--especially the last one--were undertaken to undermine Hillary C. as a candidate. So, don't get all holier-than-thou about efforts by one party to undermine the other.

Nonsense, he has ZERO evidence.  Just conjecture.  We seen his Russian reset, his uranium deal, and his promise he can do more once he is elected.  And we seen his interference in the Israeli elections, BLATANT.

While he took some punitive steps, President Obama and his cabinet understood that the foreign ties are more of a matter for intelligence agents than for politics.

Yes, it is sad. It's sad that Donald Trump cannot be trusted to put America first as he makes decisions in the Oval Office. His priorities are to protect the legitimacy of his election by denying allegations and disputing intelligence/evidence.

Obama administration officials were just being prudent considering possession and control of that intelligence/evidence would transfer to Trump's appointees on Inauguration Day.

It would have been foolish to simply hand over that information to the very people who may have been conspiring with the Russians to defeat Hillary Clinton.

It's astounding to think of a an American president letting this happen and then responding by expelling 35 Russians.
